abstract.text: Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
3D SceneKit content drawn as a flattened sprite.
A node that plays audio.
A node that determines which parts of the scene are visible within a view.
A node that masks pixels drawn by its children so that only some pixels are seen.
A node that renders its children into a separate buffer, optionally applying an effect, before drawing the final result.
A source of various particle effects.
A node that applies physics effects to nearby nodes.
A graphical element that draws text.
A node that lights surrounding nodes.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
An array of user interface elements that represent children of this element.
The size of this user interface element, in screen points.
The help description of this user interface element; for example, the text shown in a tooltip.
Returns the frontmost user interface element in the element hierarchy.
A short description of this user interface element.
The user interface element that contains this element.
A string value describing the user interface element type; for example, a button.
A string value describing the user interface element name and type; for example, the Buy button.
A string that defines this user interface elementâ€™s subrole; for example, a full-screen button.
Returns an action associated with a specific key.

The transparency value applied to the nodeâ€™s contents.

A list of constraints to apply to the node.

Converts a point in this nodeâ€™s coordinate system to the coordinate system of another node in the node tree.
The GameplayKit entity this node represents.

A rectangle in the parentâ€™s coordinate system that contains the nodeâ€™s content, ignoring the nodeâ€™s children.

Called when a node is initialized from an .sks file.

Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether this node intersects the specified node.
A toggle you implement to indicate to the system whether this user interface element should be exposed to the user.
A toggle you implement to indicate to the system whether this user interface element should respond to user input.
Compares the parameter node to the receiving node.
A Boolean value that determines whether a node and its descendants are rendered.
A Boolean value that determines whether actions on the node and its descendants are processed.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the node receives touch events.
Moves the node to a new parent node in the scene.
The nodeâ€™s assignable name.
Creates a new node.
Returns an array of all visible descendants that intersect a point.
Converts each node into an obstacle by transforming its bounds into the sceneâ€™s coordinate system.
Converts each node into an obstacle by transforming the nodeâ€™s physics body shape into the sceneâ€™s coordinate system.
Turns each node into an obstacle by changing the nodeâ€™s texture into a physics shape and converting it into the sceneâ€™s coordinate system.
The nodeâ€™s parent node.
The physics body associated with the node.
The position of the node in its parentâ€™s coordinate system.
The reach constraints to apply to the node when executing a reach action.
Removes an action associated with a specific key.
Ends and removes all actions from the node.
Removes all of the nodeâ€™s children.
Removes a list of children from the receiving node.
Removes the receiving node from its parent.
Adds an action to the list of actions executed by the node.
Adds an action to the list of actions executed by the node and schedules the argument block to be run upon completion of the action.
Adds an identifiable action to the list of actions executed by the node.
The scene node that contains this node.

A scaling factor that multiplies the height of a node and its children.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
An abstract class that forms the basis of event and command processing in AppKit.
An abstract interface for responding to and handling events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an objectâ€™s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
